results.title: Teja: a Sikh priest
results.creator_credit: Michael Rubetzki, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our multicultural society”
Describes the Indian Sikh community in Woolgoolga, in New South Wales, and Teja Singh, the community priest. Explores his role in the preservation of the culture, traditions and religion of the old life in India, and his view of the necessary changes and adaptations that the future will bring.

results.title: Pak Menggung: a Javanese aristocrat
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Keith Gow, John Morris and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours. Indonesia”.
Java is no longer ruled by kings and queens. The aristocrats who remain live in their palaces, but they are mostly poor. When they die so will many of their traditions. This passing history is recorded by following the daily life of Pak Menggung, writer and collector of ancient Keris. This film gives insight into the courtly traditions of art, etiquette and ceremony of Java. Photography is by famous Australian cinematographer, Don McAlpine.

results.title: Mastri: a Balinese woman
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, John Morris and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours. Indonesia”.
Mastri and Sukit are a young couple from the village on Tunjuk in South Bali. Sukit is a school teacher. They live in the house of Sukit’s parents and are saving their money to build a house of their own. Tunjuk has its own small dance company and Gong orchestra which is sometimes invited to perform at the tourist hotels around Denpasar, and Mastri is one of the principal dancers. The film contrasts normal village life with the “tourist’s” Bali and shows something of the religious life of the people of Tunjuk. Camerman Don McAlpine.

results.title: Azhari Ali: an Acehnese university student
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Keith Gow, John Morris and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours: Indonesia”.
Set in the city of Banda Acec, this film traces the daily life of Azhari Ali, a student of agriculture at the University of Syiah Kuala. He is a devout Moslem. His lodgings and some money were provided by the Mosque authorities. This money provides his travel to the University, some extra money is gained by teaching the Koran five nights a week. Only late at night can this ambitious 25 year-old find time to study away from his daily commitments.

results.title: G'day sport
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Frontiers downunder”.
A slightly different look at a nation that is apparently “sports mad”. This malady and the sort of sporting competition need for most Australians is examined, as well as the extremes that people in the outback go to in order to satisfy their competitive needs

results.title: Frontiers downunder
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Frontiers downunder”.
The first in a series of six films depicting life in Australia in the late 1970’s. It is a compilation of some of the footage and subject matter of the other five films, and is a very brief look at the complexities that go to make up this huge southland - the largest island in the world. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Questions
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Bruce Moir and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours: India”.
The “God rich colony” is a huge industrial estate on the outskirts of Bombay. It is a self-contained company town where everything is provided for the factory workers and their families, including schools. An Australian director and a group of 15 year-old school children have a relaxed discussion about their concept of the Australian way of life and their lives in India.

results.title: Greg
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
An exploration of the lifestyle of a middle-class family in an affluent suburb and the family’s attitudes to success, competitiveness, and the raising of children. Greg attends an independent school whilst his younger brother, Richard, attends a government high school. An important theme in the film is the extent to which Greg is making, or is able to make, autonomous decisions about his own life.

results.title: Craig and Steven
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
An exploration of the concept of masculinity. Craig is a ballet student and Steve is an Australian rules footballer. They discuss their views of life.
